events.originalText: The first phase of the Marmaray project opened with an undersea rail tunnel (train pictured) across the Bosphorus strait.
events.subtitle: Marmaray
events.headline: Marmaray project opens with undersea rail tunnel across Bosphorus strait

events.originalText: Hurricane Sandy, the largest Atlantic hurricane on record, made landfall in New Jersey and caused nearly $75 billion in damages, becoming the second-most destructive storm in U.S. history.
events.subtitle: Hurricane Sandy
events.headline: Hurricane Sandy causes $75 billion in damages in New Jersey

events.originalText: About 10,000 people died when a tropical cyclone made landfall in the Indian state of Odisha near the city of Bhubaneswar.
events.subtitle: 1999 Odisha cyclone
events.headline: Tropical cyclone in Odisha kills 10,000 near Bhubaneswar

events.originalText: At 77 years old, former astronaut John Glenn (pictured) returned to space aboard the Space Shuttle Discovery on the STS-95 mission.
events.subtitle: John Glenn
events.headline: John Glenn returns to space at 77 years old aboard Space Shuttle Discovery

events.originalText: Galileo became the first spacecraft to visit an asteroid when it made a flyby of 951 Gaspra.
events.subtitle: Galileo (spacecraft)
events.headline: Galileo spacecraft visits asteroid 951 Gaspra

events.originalText: British prime minister Margaret Thatcher officially opened the M25, one of Britain's busiest motorways.
events.subtitle: Margaret Thatcher
events.headline: Margaret Thatcher opens M25 motorway in Britain

events.originalText: A C-46 airliner carrying the Cal Poly Mustangs football team crashed during takeoff from Toledo Express Airport in Ohio, U.S., resulting in 22 deaths.
events.subtitle: Curtiss C-46 Commando
events.headline: Cal Poly Mustangs football team plane crash kills 22 in Ohio

events.originalText: Israeli Border Police massacred 48 Arab citizens of Kafr Qasim, among them women and children who were returning from work.
events.subtitle: Israel Border Police
events.headline: Israeli Border Police massacre 48 Arab citizens in Kafr Qasim

events.originalText: An explosion, likely caused by a World War II–era naval mine, capsized the Soviet ship Novorossiysk in the harbor of Sevastopol, with the loss of 608 men.
events.subtitle: Naval mine
events.headline: Soviet ship Novorossiysk capsized in Sevastopol harbor, 608 men lost

events.originalText: Arab–Israeli War: The Israel Defense Forces massacred at least 52 villagers while capturing the Palestinian Arab village of Safsaf.
events.subtitle: 1948 Arab–Israeli War
events.headline: Israel Defense Forces massacre 52 villagers in Safsaf during Arab-Israeli War

events.originalText: The Nanbu clan of Honshu surrendered to imperial forces during the Boshin War.
events.subtitle: Nanbu clan
events.headline: Nanbu clan surrenders to imperial forces during Boshin War

events.originalText: American Civil War: The Battle of Wauhatchie, one of the few night battles of the war, concluded with the Union Army opening a supply line to troops in Chattanooga, Tennessee.
events.subtitle: American Civil War
events.headline: Battle of Wauhatchie concludes with Union Army opening supply line to Chattanooga

events.originalText: Rioting broke out in Bristol, England, after the Second Reform Bill failed to pass parliament, causing 250 casualties and £300,000 of damage (pictured).
events.subtitle: 1831 Bristol riots
events.headline: Rioting in Bristol after Second Reform Bill fails in parliament, 250 casualties

events.originalText: William Robert Broughton, a member of George Vancouver's expedition, observed a peak in the present-day U.S. state of Oregon and named it Mount Hood after British admiral Samuel Hood.
events.subtitle: William Robert Broughton
events.headline: William Robert Broughton names peak in Oregon Mount Hood after British admiral
